nano.remexp.net
Class NanoSocket

java.lang.Object
  nano.remexp.ThreadHandler
      nano.remexp.net.NanoSocket
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
Direct Known Subclasses:
EventSocket, StreamSocket
public abstract class NanoSocket
extends ThreadHandler

The lowest layer of the communication between the different architectural parts. Through this we are able to observe all currently running sockets and close them if they aren't useful anymore.

Version:
1.1 23.08.2012
Author:
Dominic Bosch

Method Detail

getRemoteID

public java.lang.String getRemoteID()
Returns the remote host's address in the format [url]:[port]

Returns:
a string containing the host address and port, e.g.: "127.0.0.1:12345"

getLastSignOfLife

public long getLastSignOfLife()
Get the last time stamp when we heard from this socket.

Returns:
the time stamp in number of milliseconds of when this socket last has been active.

gotLifeSign

public void gotLifeSign()
Since we heard from this socket, the time stamp is updated.

isActiveSocket

public boolean isActiveSocket()
Returns the information whether this socket should be active

Returns:
true if it is in a an active state (e.g. the stream socket during scanning), else false FIXME this active state in the stream socket needs to be checked during measurements

setActiveSocket

protected void setActiveSocket(boolean theTruth)

getRemoteHost

public java.lang.String getRemoteHost()
Tries to get information about the socket.

Returns:
The url of the remote host if the socket existed, else '[NONE]'

getRemotePort

protected int getRemotePort()
Retrieves the remote port of this socket.

Returns:
The port to which this socket is connected.

put

public void put(byte[] b)
Writes a number of bytes onto the socket.

Parameters:
b - the byte array to be sent.

This method should be overwritten by the classes that extend this basic class.

ping

public abstract void ping()
Should implement the ping logic for this socket in order to check it for connectivity.

removeYourself

protected abstract void removeYourself()
This method needs to implement the logic if the socket should remove itself.

shutDown

public void shutDown()
Description copied from class: ThreadHandler
Important! every implementation of the shutDown method has to call stopThread in order to be sure the thread is being shut down! (or otherwise set thisThread=null) Else the doTask method will be called over and over again and the thread won't die.

Specified by:
shutDown in class ThreadHandler
